t: Proverbs 11
A*pn false balance is an abomination to the Lord,*s but*ld a just weight is his delight.
When*ln pride comes, then comes disgrace, but*ld with the humble is wisdom.
The*ln integrity of the upright guides them, but*ld the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.
Riches*ln do not profit in the day of wrath, but*ld righteousness delivers from death.
The*ln righteousness of the blameless keeps his way straight, but*ld the wicked falls by his own wickedness.
The*ln righteousness of the upright delivers them, but*ld the treacherous are taken captive by their lust.
When*ln the wicked dies, his hope will perish, and*ld the expectation of wealth perishes too.
The*ln righteous is delivered from trouble, and*ld the wicked walks into it instead.
With*ln his mouth the godless man would destroy his neighbor, but*ld by knowledge the righteous are delivered.
When*ln it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices, and*ld when the wicked perish there are shouts of gladness.
By*ln the blessing of the upright a city is exalted, but*ld by the mouth of the wicked it is overthrown.
Whoever*ln belittles his neighbor lacks sense, but*ld a man of understanding remains silent.
Whoever*ln goes about slandering reveals secrets, but*ld he who is trustworthy in spirit keeps a thing covered.
Where*ln there is no guidance, a people falls, but*ld in an abundance of counselors there is safety.
Whoever*ln puts up security for a stranger will surely suffer harm, but*ld he who hates striking hands in pledge is secure.
A*ln gracious woman gets honor, and*ld violent men get riches.
A*ln man who is kind benefits himself, but*ld a cruel man hurts himself.
The*ln wicked earns deceptive wages, but*ld one who sows righteousness gets a sure reward.
Whoever*ln is steadfast in righteousness will live, but*ld he who pursues evil will die.
Those*ln of crooked heart are an abomination to the Lord,*s but*ld those of blameless ways are his delight.
Be*ln assured, an evil person will not go unpunished, but*ld the offspring of the righteous will be delivered.
Like*ln a gold ring in a pigâ€™s snout is*ld a beautiful woman without discretion.
The*ln desire of the righteous ends only in good, the*ld expectation of the wicked in wrath.
One*ln gives freely, yet grows all the richer; another*ld withholds what he should give, and only suffers want.
Whoever*ln brings blessing will be enriched, and*ld one who waters will himself be watered.
The*ln people curse him who holds back grain, but*ld a blessing is on the head of him who sells it.
Whoever*ln diligently seeks good seeks favor, but*ld evil comes to him who searches for it.
Whoever*ln trusts in his riches will fall, but*ld the righteous will flourish like a green leaf.
Whoever*ln troubles his own household will inherit the wind, and*ld the fool will be servant to the wise of heart.
The*ln fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and*ld whoever captures souls is wise.
If*ln the righteous is repaid on earth, how*ld much more the wicked and the sinner!
